Posts.Title: Radiation dosage nanabolini knowledgeforpower

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 03:40PM O3132W wrote: Robolegs:  My answer to your question might be found in my own experience.  I am 72 years old and have always had my mamogram yearly at a hospital without event.  Then on Nov. 2005 my mammogram showed a suspicious spot.  The Radiogist who reads the xrays had an ultrasound done which showed nothing then for the next two years I was instructed to have this right breast xrayd based on diagnostic every six months.  Each time the spot showed up however the radiologist was checking for any changes or movement or growth and found none.  Then in April 2009 during my annual mammogram the radialogist had an ultrasound done and said she recommended me to  have a sterotactic biopsy done as she saw some raggy edges on the spot.  The hospital had also just updated their mammogram equipment to digital which they said would produce better pictures.  I had the biopsy done a week later which was not a lot of pain and found that I had DCIS.  Next step lumpectomy which now showed invasive cancer which means some cancer had escaped from the duct.  Next step:  radiation scheduled for August 2009.  Guess looking back I would have had the sterotactic biopsy done when they first found spot.  It is not that painful and would have changed everything for me.  This is what I would advise my daughter to do if she finds any suspicious spots on her mammograms.  Cancer is not something one would want to guess about.   Although the radialogist trys to read a mammogram accuratly, he/she is limited but a biopsy answers the questions. Why take any chance when it comes to Cancer?  Hope this helps you.
Posts.Title: 6 month wait okay? KimberleyGL cookiemom

Posts.Content: O3132W wrote: At 250 pounds and 72 years old , that hard hard table is doing a number on my back.  The pain is far worse than the pain in my arms during my treatments which is bad enough.    After my treatments I take lots of pain meds which are upsetting my stomach.  I called my pharmasist to ask if I could take three things at once:  An anxiety pill, a tylenel 3 and a celebrex tomorrow morning as the already painful 5 minutes for treatment is going to increase to 10-15 minutes while they take xrays before my treatment.  How in the world will I get through tomorrow??????  Finished #5 today with 11 to go.  Thanks for all of your help to get me to this point.   Cathey Dx 5/29/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Too much pain in back???? O3132W bethaib

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 09:37PM - edited Aug 11, 2009 09:40PM by O3132W LAURA:  I had my simulation last tuesday and my set-up today with my first radiation treatment.  I learned a few things that I want to share with you.  I ask point blank my rad onc the % or reoccurance I face.  He told me that after I had my Lump surgery my reoccurance percentage was 30%.  I am doing the shortened 3 weeks radiation which will be once per day X 16 treatments.  My Doc told me that when I finish this 3 wks that my reoccurance percentage will be 5%.  I feel really good about this and I will have a number of questions to ask my medical onc when I have my first appt this thursday.  Im sure she will add to my knowledge enabling me toward my best decisions.  Just to tell you the simulation was difficult but the set up was worse as it is hard for my 72 year old body to hold still for the time needed for mapping.  I also have to say that the radiation treatment today was one of those times that you want to ask the tech "have you done it yet? As I felt nothing and rad lasted about 20 seconds."  Doc gave me prescription for Biafine Emulson, comes in a tube  and I am supposed to cover breast with it  twice a day but not within 4 hours of treatment.   They tell me that I should be in and out in 15 minutes per treatment.  Except one day per week when they do xray pictures to re-verify location of rads.  I meet the criteria for 3 wk as small breasts, small tumor, negative for nodes.  Time will tell if I have made the right decision to have the shortened rads. but for now I am satisfied with my decision.   Good luck   Cathey
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2009 09:32PM - edited Aug 13, 2009 09:33PM by O3132W NANAB:  Lots of women on these threads will have lots of advise.  I know this as their advise  made my experience tolerable.  I am doing my 4th rad treatment tomorrow out of 16. ( The shortened 3 wk radiation treatments. ) So far-so good.   For the benefit of back pain in this old 72 year old body and .laying on the hard HARD table with your arms above your head for 45 minutes was hard for me and  pain medicine taken before simulation and set-up helped me.  The treatments themselves only last 15-20 minutes and you feel nothing, like you might ask the tech. if she has done it yet.  As I have just started, I dont know much about side-effects but my rad onc gave ma a prescription for 3 tubes of Biafin Topical Emulsion to protect my breast from burn.  I hope it works.  Our Dx is almost the same  Good luck to you.  Cathey
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2009 05:35PM - edited Oct 8, 2009 05:35PM by O3132W nanpar:  I am also age 72 and also diabetic and have just finished 16 radiation treatments after Lump. on June 30. Energy and sleeplessness is standard.  I had the shortened 3 week radiation plan and did very well.  I am just now beginning to regain some small amount of energy.  A little more each day.  If you wish you may PM me for details.  My two children took turns and cleaned and vaccumed as it is not good to use the arm for anything repeatitive.  I slept in a chair for about a week.  My blood sugars went up to concerning levels and I was told that it is to be expected due to anesthia during surgery and stress afterward.  I was getting readings up to 350 and now a couple of months later am beginning to have control again and getting readings of average of about 130.  I wondered why none of my medical team was concerned but as I said now I am getting control. (with food and pills) Its a very scary time for an older lady but doable.  The most pain I experienced during radiation was my back laying on that hard hard table.  I started taking a tylenol 3 before the treatment and it helped.  Good luck to you and your Mom.   Cathey from Indiana

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2009 07:31PM O3132W wrote: Had simulation this morning, part 1.   Next Monday I will have the second part followed by treatments.  Lasted 30 minutes.  My arms and shoulders and back hurt a little but found it was doable.  Thanks. Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2009 12:42AM O3132W wrote: AusMum:  Glad for you that this part is over for you and we all understand how difficult it is to wait for your path. report.    Yes, ice helps to keep the surgical area from swelling. By the second day you might want to put ice on spot about 15 minutes every hour.  Wrap ice or frozen peas in a light weight towel and put on spot.  Not too much cold for too long a time.  Keep it up at least until you have your post-surgery appointment.   Thats what I did and kept it from swelling which helps healing.   I am now 8 days after Lump. surgery and got my pathology report on the 7th day.  Another thing if no one has told you is to wear a sport bra 24 hours a day for the first two weeks.  Get one that closes in the front. I even shower with it on to protect the stitches.  Dont know if you have a Walmart there but they have sport bras cheap.  I hate wearing the bra but I know that it holds the breast firmly but gentle which protects the stitches from injury allowing them to heal better.  I stopped pain meds on the fourth day but this you have to decide how long  you need .  Allow yourself as much comfort as possible.  I cannot sleep in my bed yet but I sleep in a recliner.  I hope this all helps you.    Did they check your lymph nodes?
Posts.Title: New and on emotional rollercoaster AusMum vivvygirl

Posts.Content: O3132W wrote: I want to share a foundation I found set up for the State of Indiana breast cancer ladies who option for chemo or radiation treatment.  I was told about www.iwinfoundation.org  from a caring associate at the radiation center where I had my treatments.  Upon contacting this foundation I asked why dont more Indiana women know about this and I was told that they did not have an advertising budget.  If you are going through treatment eg. Chemo or radiation you can receive $500.00 of credit that may be used by you for such things as childcare, pet care, gas cards, restaurant gift cards and more.  The list is on their site.  Relatives are not elligible for this money and no regard for income.  I completed the application and my rad onc signed that I am going through radiation and then I got a call from the foundation telling me that I was accepted for the $500.00 and what could they do for me.  I asked for a $100  gas card at BP and a $100 gift card for Steak and Shake and I received both the next day.   This $500 is good for six months from being accepted. If you are as sceptical as I am, I urge you to check out the site.  It works for me. What a help this has been for me.  Using my gas card helps me with money for my prescriptions. I cant say enough about this wonderful foundation that was set up by a nurse.  Check it out!!!  Cathey Dx 5/29/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2009 05:36PM - edited Aug 3, 2009 05:38PM by O3132W So sorry anxiousmomma that you had such a terrible experience.  I know how nervous you had to be without the added inefficient office staff member with an attitute.    Most physicians have an office manager which you might approach first.  After you get home, call back in and ask to speak to the office manager.  If there is no office manager then it is time to have a very private talk with the rad. onc. (THE BOSS)    This is his/her office and he/she needs to know if his/her staff is satisfying his/her patients.  My guess is that he/she will be grateful for you for trusting him/her to correct the problems of the staff.    I am the type of patient that will speak out, if not for me, for the hundreds of patients who find it, for thousands of reasons, impossible to speak out.  We need to help each other through this mire of insurance companies, labs, consultants, surgeons, hospitals etc, etc, etc.  This interaction can be overwhelming to people who are new to the medical world.. On its best day this whole thing is confusing to the layman who is unfamiliar with how to navigate.  Good luck    Cathey from Indiana
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2009 08:51PM O3132W wrote: lemonjello:     I know just how you feel.  My 72 year old body suffers each and every day.  My back just breaks from that hard hard table.  I try as hard as I can to relax but I can feel all my muscles like rocks and all I can think of is ":is it over yet?"  Lately I have been counting the sounds during the treatment.  5 sounds on my left and then 3 sounds on my right then I know it is over for that day.  At first the arms just about go numb  but that is getting easier. I also see the doc every tuesday after an extra long treatment including xrays to check positioning.  Tomorrow I have lots of questions for the rad onc.  Small cough with dry throat?  Why are my blood sugars high (I am diabetic)  Pink but not red yet.  I am doing the shortened 3 week radiation and had #10 today and 6 to go.  I should be finished a week from Tuesday.  I dont want to think of whats next.  I guess we have no choice but every so often we can vent.  Luck Cathey
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 11:50AM O3132W wrote: Unless there are more surprises, tomorrow will be my last radiation treatment.  I have optioned for the shortened 3 week radiation treatments (16 in total) and as today have no regrets.  Not sure whats next but Im sure they will tell me.  I have a little light tan look but my back is quite painful from laying on that hard table.  I will be glad it will be over tomorrow.  Cathey from Indiana
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 06:30PM O3132W wrote: cake is great:     Shortness of breath caused me to ask the rad onc if my lung was compromised from the treatments.  He reached over to my last xray and showed me the "yes" extent that my lung was exposed on the xray  He showed me where on my body the rays hit and it was above the nipple and to the center of my breast. (Right one)   He did however tell me that the only thing I would experience in my future was that this very small part of my lung will show up on a future xray as a shaded area which might cause the tech to suggest pneumona, and I should tell them of my radiation. This exposure caused me to have a small dry cought and shortness of breath but I will add that it is getting better now, 1 1/2 weeks after last treatment.  You might want to ask your rad onc to show you your latest xray and ask if your lung has been compromised.  Take care   Cathey
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 12:20AM O3132W wrote: Count me in on this thread.  My Simulation is scheduled for Aug. 4 and I assume rad. treatments start soon after.  I am fair and I am hoping that my skin can handle rads.  Had lump. surgery on June 30 with SLB.  Removed very small DCIS with clear margins and nodes negative for cancer. So far, healing well with help from my two grown children.  I  have only had three panic crys and I feel that I am doing well, both physically and emotionally. I had a terrible time with the decision to have radiation but after a lot of research and many sleepless nights, I finally decided to have radiation.  As a diabetic, I choose not to have mammosite due to the exposure to various posible infections.   Of the remaining options I choose the shortened three week radiation.  I hope all of us have safe and successful radiation treatments without problems.  Cathey from Indiana

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2009 08:39PM O3132W wrote: I am small breasted and have not worn a bra for many years so this is not a problem for me.  I latter up twice a day with Biafin Topical Emulsion (prescribed by rad onc) and then wear a soft camesole.  I just finished my 4th treatment and so far so good.  I have seen that Walmart has low cost front closer sports bras up to a size 40 for less than $10. Funny true story:  Once worked in an office with a disagreeable co-worker to everyone.  One day someone during the lunch break put a large box of X-lax on her desk with four words.  "Hopes this helps you" signed the company name.  Creative huh?   Good luck

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2009 05:45PM O3132W wrote: Hi ladies;  This AM #13 of 16 , with 3 to go.  Cant wait to finish.  No bra however bought 3 soft anti static camisoles.  I use one under street clothes.  I use one to sleep in to protect my skin. I use the third to wear as I spreadi the prescribed Biafin Topical Emulsion on breast which smears the sharpie marks on this camisole.  It does wash out and this system works well for me.  Take care of your selves.   Cathey

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 08:15PM O3132W wrote: LoriRR:    Thanks for your response,  So glad you are almost done and without terrible side effects of breast burn.  Great.  Hope I am that lucky.  My rad onc tells me that he plans to do 16 treatments and no boosts.  His partner is the doc that usually performs the 3 week and my onc is following his prodical.  Makes me feel more secure in that I have the knowledge of two onc docs on my team.  The set up this morning was much worse than I had anticipated.  It took 45 minutes and I thought my back was going to break and my arms and shoulders were really hurting.  I guess thats my worse day and it gets better from here.  They tell me that I should be in and out in 15 minutes.  Sounds good to me.  However, on day per week they need to do a repeat set up but not as long a time.  I think I can tolerate one day a week especially doing only three weeks.  I had thought of cold cloths but afraid that this would dry the skin out.  Have you not had any cracking or peeling or burning?  How fortunate for you.  Maybe they have done so much of these 3 wk'ers that they have learned how to do them without the terrible side effects some women experience.  Thanks Lori     Cathey
Posts.Title: Radiation #1 of 16 done today. O3132W O3132W

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2009 07:18PM O3132W wrote: Jeannette:  No you are not the oldest on this site.  I will be 73 in three weeks and was dx with bc and had my lump. surgery June 30, 2009.  You will have many many questions and fears and comments in the next few months.  Be aware that you have found the right place for your voice. I myself am a person who wants to know everything and I cannot accept the just dont tell me approach.  I am also a research person who uses the internet for most of my answers.  I have learned one thing I didnt know and that is that you are in charge.  So educate yourself and ask, ask, ask.  The ladies on this site are forthcomming and have made the difference for me.  I will be forever grateful for these brave women.  Find the personal message section and communicate with ladies who are knowledgable in your questions.  Good Luck   It really does get better.  Cathey from Indiana
Posts.Title: I think I'm the oldest one here! Chevyboy Chevyboy

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2009 08:42PM O3132W wrote: Remember you asked.   In my case my original sterotactic biopsy was mildly painful.  More fear than actural pain.  I had my lump with SNB on June 30.  First was the wire location which I found to be less pain than the sterotactic biopsy.  Then off the the surgical center for the prep for SNB.  The normal procedure was to lay down on a hard table to have the four needles done however as I am 72 years old with back problems, I requested that they perform the needle shots while I was seated in a wheelchair.  They granted me my request and I think it was better and possibly less painful.  With four black marks at the four directions about one inch inward on the breast from the nipple (needles do not go in in the mipple)  I would not be honest with you if I told you that these four shots are without pain.  I am accepting that you asked for truth and in my case each shot was extremely painful however on the bright side they only penitrate just under the skin and they do not last more than 5 seconds each.  Within 5 minutes after this procedure is complete there is no pain at all.  As I am the kind of woman who can get through things as long as I know what to expect.  Surprises panic me.   Hope this detail helps you  I am two weeks post my Lump. and I am doing very well.  In four more weeks I will be having the 3 wk shortened radiation.  Good luck to you.   Cathey/Indiana
Posts.Title: Fear of sentinal node biopsy warren3 2Hands4me

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 04:23PM O3132W wrote: Had #6 of 16 this morning.  This is the day of the week where they have you laying on that hard hard table for an extra few minutes while they take xray pictures.  As my back screams at the regular treatment I was not sure how I could get through this additional time.  Let me tell you what I did.  Appointment at 9:45 AM.  At 8:30 am took one celebrex and one tylenol 3 together.  They took effect by 10:00 and helped me get through the Tuesday treatment.  For any of you ladies who has back problems maybe this will help you.  Good luck Cathey
Posts.Title: Radiation #1 of 16 done today. O3132W O3132W

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2009 10:43PM - edited Aug 17, 2009 10:47PM by O3132W CAPHAN:  Ask your surgeon and or rad onc if you are a candidate for the shortened 3 week radiation treatment plan.  I choose this plan as I am a candidate.  Small breasts, clear margins, small tumor, and lymph nodes negative.  Talk to them about this plan, it might be a good one for you.  I was told that re occurance percent after surgery was 30% and after radiation down to 5%.
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 07:14PM O3132W wrote: Kawee: Biafin Topical Emulsion is in a tube and is via prescription.  Ask your rad. onc for a prescription.  Luck
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2009 07:04PM O3132W wrote: lemonyellow:     I could have signed my name to your post.  SO TRUE   The only thing you left out was the sleepless nights of  one hour and then awake and over and over throughout the night of sleeplessness and dry coughing.  Add to that the unwelcome hot flashes that repeat through covers or no covers fight all night.  I had #14 of 16 shortened rad treatments this AM. Only two to go Monday and Tuesday.  Yes ladies it does finally end even if you dont think it will.  The emulsion cream prescribed by my rad onc kept my breast light pink with just a little redish under.  Guess it was good cream.  I have been warned to continue using creams for a couple of weeks after end of radiation as the breast can still go to red, blisters etc after last treatment.  Luck to all.   Cathey
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2009 03:29PM O3132W wrote: flowerpower:     You are a week ahead of me  My simulation is Aug. 4.  Can you describe your simulation.  Is it done different for the right breast?  How long did it take where you had to hold still?  Thanks  Cathey from Indiana
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 05:26PM - edited Aug 12, 2009 05:33PM by O3132W CHRIS:  I  had my second rad treatment today and I met another lady who I asked if she also was told to use Biafin Topical Emulsion to keep her breast from burning. She showed me her breast which was not even pink after her 20th treatment.  She said she really spreads this emulsion on thick at least twice a day and has had no burning.  I hope Im that lucky.  It does not smell and does not feel sticky.  It is water soluable and must be removed at least 4 hours before a treatment.   Three large tubes cost about $200 in Indpls without insurance.  After my insurance it cost me $35.00.  A lot of money but worth it is it gets me through the breastburn.  Good luck.     Cathey
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 02:53PM O3132W wrote: LoriR     No, Ive never heard that they need to burn the skin.  I am having 16 treatments at 2.67 grays per treatment equaling a total of 42.72 Grays (or units)    Had #9 this AM and so far my skin is not even pink.  I am however loading on the Biafin Topical Emulsion  prescribed by my rad. onc.   I am beginning to feel just a little tired but so far so good.  I am anxious to read if anyone else has heard of burning the skin intentionally.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 06:03PM O3132W wrote: ravenruth:  I am currently taking the 3 week radiation (16 treatments)  First you have to be a candidate.  Such things as small breasted, small tumor, clean margins and negative nodes.  This program was not offered to me until I requested it.  First I asked my surgeon and she said that I would be a candidate and then I spoke to the radiation center onc. and told him that this is the program I want.  He approved and I got started.  This AM I had my #9 out of 16 and so far so good.  My breast is not pink yet and other than being a little tired I am not experiencing any other s/e as of today. I also slosh lots of Biafin Topical Emulsion (prescription) on my breast after treatment.  My treatments last about 15 minutes in and out.  Once a week they make an xray proofing location for extra caution which adds 5 minutes to treatment.  Each treatment gives me 2.67 units (grays) equaling a total amount of grays of 42.72 which is less than the 50 grays for the 33 treatment plan.  As my surgeon told me that the results of shortened or standard are the same you might want to discuss it with your rad onc.  Luck to you   Cathey
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 06:28PM O3132W wrote: I have been told that I should not wear any deoderant on either breast while doing radiation due to some ingredient in it that is bad for radiation.  I guess there is some kind of deoderant that does not contain a harmful ingredient but it is very expensive.  Your rad nurse would be able to give you its name and where you can buy it.  I choose not to wear any until rad is over. I do however smear on my breast twice a day the Biafin Topical Emulsion that my rad onc prescribed for me. Even this Emulsion must be washed off at least 4 hours before a radiation treatment.  It is water soluable and easy to remove and not sticky,  It really feels good and goes on easily.  Friday was #9 with 7 to go and so far I am not even pink but I am beginning to feel tiredness in my legs.  But I have not hit the wall yet from fatique.  Maybe next week. Hope not. As far as the qualifications for the shortened rad, your rad onc should be able to decide if you are a candidate. There are many sites that descibe lots of details on the 3 week radiation treatments  One can be found on this site which will tell you about it.  Luck
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2009 07:21AM O3132W wrote: ALYED;  I just cringed as I read your comments.  I cant imagine anything worse than having to lay on that stone table one minute longer and you went through the worst.  I am so sorry this happened to you and hope with all my heart that the rest of your treatments go as they should.  Yesterday was my #11 of 16 (shortened radiation) and I thought that I had it bad as they had me lay 5 minutes longer than normal to get xray picture.  I will never complain again.  You take the prize for worst day in my opinion.  Cathey
Posts.Title: AUGUST 2009 RADS Alyad ChrisC433

Posts.Content: O3132W wrote: Friday was my 4th treatment in a 16 treatment plan.  I am just starting to feel a little soreness in right arm pit.  Normal????  Using Biafin Topical Emulsion on breast and so far so good as to burning on breast.  Five more treatments next 5 days.  Still dont know what hurts worse my back or my arms.  On tuesday they plan to take xray pictures before treatment and really anxious about that long a time on Hard table.  I asked the techs if they could put something soft at my back and they said only if it does not raise my body any.  Guess I will load up on Tylenol 3 and Celebrex before Tuesday.  Any other suggestions.     Thanks Cathey Dx 5/29/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 3-week radiation treatment O3132W knowledgeforpower

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 05:28PM O3132W wrote: All of the replies you have received are correct.  The performance is nothing as you are in lala land and are unaware, however the preparation is a bear.  Yes you will be on the toilet most of the night.  The best advise I can give you is to keep a jar of vasoline near the toilet and just smear it on the effected area each time you need it.  This will help you from getting sore as you get through the night.  Another thing is to watch what you eat a day or two befor the colon. Keep all food bland and stay away from spicy foods.  Good luck  I remember my first colonoscopy and how nervous I was.  I have one every five years and are no longer afraid.
Posts.Title: MY FIRST COLONOSCOPY - ANY ADVICE? Godlistens BarbaraA

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 09:11PM O3132W wrote: Knowledgeforpower:  I, like you are going to have the 3 week program.  Now that you are finished, do you regret having the 3 week instead of the 5-6 week?  Did you feel that the increase in rads per treatment in 3 wk. caused you any increase in soreness over less rads for the 5-6 week     Do you have any suggestions that I might do?  Did you have any appitite change?  When did you start putting the aloe on breast?  Did you crack or peel?.  Both my surgeon and my rad. onc. tell me that the results are the same for shortened or longer rad. programs.  Fortunately I am a candicate for the 3 week and will start next week.  So far, I have had the simulation including the CT scan and they marked my breast with India ink and made a mold of my back with my arms above my head.  .  Next Tuesday they tell me that they will be checking the ink spots for accuracy.  Laying on that very hard table hurts my back and arms and I am looking forward to starting the actual treatments which they say will last about 15 minutes.  So far I have not seen an onc doc so I do not know what I need to do after radiation.  I have osteopenia in my bones and wonder if this will effect future treatments.   Thank you for your help.  Cathey.

Posts.Content: O3132W wrote: Had my simulation yesterday and rad. onc. told me that when I am finished with my treatment program  (3 week program) that the radiated breast will be significantly smaller in size.  Has anyone out there found this to be true?   How much smaller?  Any other after effects that I should know about?   Thanks Dx 5/29/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Radiated breast smaller? O3132W O3132W

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 11:39PM O3132W wrote: knowledgeforpower:  Thanks for the quick response.  Where did you get the aloe vera?  Did your rad. onc give it to you?  Also where did you get acquaphor?  I would love to start using aloe right away however they told me not to shower or use anything on my breast that would wash away the ink marks.  My guess is that when I go in next tuesday that they might do a tatoo which would enable me to start using aloe.  So far no one has told me to get any kind of lotion.  Glad to hear that you dont regret the 3 week treatment.  My guess is that one's breast will get sore and tender whichever treatment you choose. I feel so fortunate that I am retired (age 72) and dont work.  This will enable me to rest all day and night and I can focus on my treatments.    Also I wont have a very long drive, about 2-3 miles.  I wish others had my advantages, it would make it easier for them.  I feel for young mothers who work and still have to fight this fight.  My heart goes out to them.  Thanks again.  Cathey
